3.10.text:
Ian Dejardin:– Now we move on to another
great artist who happens to be a woman, a

9.76.text:
sculptor in this case, Kathleen Scott. I find
her also fascinating. Clearly a virtuoso sculptor,

18.49.text:
I mean, her sculpture nearby of Robert Falcon
Scott down at Waterloo Place is a really very

25.54.text:
beautiful piece of work and she does many
other things as well. A specialist, clearly,

31.20.text:
in portrait busts to perhaps not as fashionable
as they might be now and in that sense, the

37.77.text:
parade that I mentioned earlier has in a way
passed her by. None the less, there is a similarity

44.35.text:
I think that Kathleen Scott is in many ways
doomed to be, to a certain extent, a footnote

54.28.text:
in the history of her first husband. Of course,
one should bear in mind that Scott of the

59.32.text:
Antarctic, they were married for two years
basically. He then disappeared off to the

65.32.text:
Antarctic and died leaving her with a one
year old child. It was a very small episode

72.48.text:
in many ways in her life and yet films are
made of Scott of the Antarctic and documentaries

78.36.text:
and books written and Kathleen Scott who had
a long and celebrated career has been, relatively

87.34.text:
speaking, forgotten. So, I'm looking forward
very much to hear what Dr Pauline Rose has

93.84.text:
to say on the subject of this sculptor. Pauline
Rose is Professor of Art History, the Arts

100.76.text:
University of Bournemouth. She’s done quite
a lot of work on Henry Moore which I find

105.02.text:
very interesting and I'm delighted to see
that she’s currently working on a book on

109.68.text:
British women sculptors from around 1890 to
around 1945, long overdue and I look forward

115.57.text:
to that very much indeed. Dr Rose’s talk
is called ‘Kathleen Scott: A Portrait of

123.04.text:
the Sculptor and her Work.’
Dr Pauline Rose:– Kathleen Scott was one

135.17.text:
of the most reviewed and successful sculptors
during the interwar years, as evidence by

140.42.text:
the numerous reports on her life and work
in newspapers and magazines. She was photographed

146.53.text:
many times, if often rather improbably dressed
for a professional sculptor, reminding the

152.11.text:
contemporary viewer of her social as well
as artistic status.

157.14.text:
In this first image she is seen working on
a bust of Lord David Cecil in 1930. However

164.30.text:
Scott does not appear in most accounts of
British sculpture owing to the insistence

168.80.text:
on Modernist practices as the dominant, or
even only, narrative in the writing of twentieth

174.35.text:
century art history. This overly dogmatic
distinction between work that is either ‘modern’

181.12.text:
or ‘traditional’ has masked the fact that
artistic influences and interests merge and

186.01.text:
shift and has also marginalised the work of
artists who were highly successful but who

192.23.text:
have subsequently become unfashionable. In
some instances it is Scott’s status as a

197.91.text:
society figure, which is conveyed in the photograph,
and this other part of her life through which

203.45.text:
she met her sitters and thus gained commissions,
hints at the parallel responsibilities experienced

209.51.text:
by woman artists, professionals, wives, mothers
and so on.

218.64.text:
In my next slide she’s been photographed
at her home in 1939 and this is typical of

224.37.text:
the many photographs of her where you would
have no idea as to her career. At the time

229.90.text:
such photographs probably drew a positive
response from viewers and the readers of accompanying

235.53.text:
articles. However, they may have subsequently
led to some art historians taking them as

240.58.text:
indicators of women artists’ essentially
domestic role and thus a lack of commitment

245.78.text:
to their profession. It has to be acknowledged
there are no photographs of Scott up to her

251.35.text:
elbows in clay and thus we have to assume
that the image conveyed was intentional. She

256.97.text:
was a woman of considerable social standing
and the photographs emphasise this, rather

261.98.text:
than her profession.
One of numerous accounts of Scott which brought

267.10.text:
together her private, domestic and public
life appeared in the sketch in February 1922

274.21.text:
where it was announced that she was to remarry.
The illustration comprised the somewhat intense

280.37.text:
Pre-Raphaelite style photograph of the sculptor
surrounded by her works, in the centre of

286.71.text:
which, top left hand corner, was a head and
shoulders portrait of her fiancé, Hilton

291.74.text:
Young MP, later to be Lord Kennet. As Ian’s
already said, her first husband was briefly

298.51.text:
Scott of the Antarctic.
Scott studied at the Slade between 1898 and

305.11.text:
1902. She showed an aptitude in modelling
in clay from life and this remained her preferred

310.40.text:
working method. She continued her studies
in Paris where Rodin had a considerable influence

316.29.text:
on the development of her style, particularly
noticeable in her use of naturalistic poses

322.15.text:
and confident modelling and he took a great
interest in her work.

327.44.text:
Between 1905 and 1909 she exhibited nine sculptures
in Paris that would have been seen alongside

334.27.text:
works by Rodin and Bourdelle. However she
had no time for Modernism and particularly

340.70.text:
disliked Epstein’s work, which she thought
was ugly. An interesting explanation of Scott’s

346.65.text:
dislike of Modernist trends, particularly
I think in relation to her portraits, was

351.37.text:
described in a 1927 article where she was
quoted as saying that, “...modern styles

357.96.text:
tend to make a set type and that makes their
likenesses uninteresting to record”. Her

364.71.text:
preference for male subjects was stated to
be because their features suggested either

369.37.text:
power or intellect and given the circles in
which she moved she was in a perfect position

374.76.text:
to find such sitters.
Scott’s work can broadly be divided into

380.34.text:
two categories. Her idealised statues of male
youths, which sometimes were also used as

385.53.text:
war memorials, and her portraits which are
usually busts but she also made statues and

392.10.text:
statuettes, in all, nearly 130 documented
portrait works. These established her prominence

399.15.text:
in British sculpture, her career reaching
its peak during the interwar years when she

403.34.text:
held six major exhibitions, three of them
solo. In 1927 Scott’s family moved to Leinster

411.01.text:
Corner on the Bayswater Road where she converted
a coach house into a two storey high studio.

419.69.text:
In 1928 she appealed for a greater interest
in sculpture as a decorative art for the house

425.62.text:
and the garden.
She commented on people’s preference for

429.34.text:
a painted rather than a sculpted portrait
of a husband, wife or children. Surmising

434.51.text:
that perhaps they believed that a bust was
only appropriate if the subject were dead.

439.83.text:
She deplored the fact that people did not
look at sculpture and that her crowded days

443.59.text:
at the Royal Academy she noted that, and I
quote, “...people only seemed to go into

448.51.text:
the sculpture rooms to sit down because there
was no room anywhere else”. She also argued

454.53.text:
for the civilising effect of sculpture in
the smallest house or in the garden. Interviews

460.79.text:
with artists have often taken place within
the context of their studios accompanied by

465.24.text:
photographs of their working and/or domestic
environment. Female artists have not been

471.26.text:
the subject of biographies to the extent of
male artists but the illustrated interview

475.87.text:
has been a way in which all artists’ lives
could be laid bare to an avid public. Studio

481.80.text:
homes have been particularly potent sources
for journalism, presenting readers with the

487.30.text:
notion of getting to know the sculptor.
In 1932 an extensive illustrated article on

493.95.text:
Scott appeared in Queen magazine. After making
the routine comment on the arduous nature

500.16.text:
of sculpture in contrast with the relative
frailty of women, the writer described in

505.70.text:
great detail Scott’s home and studio. The
article included several photographs. The

516.86.text:
slide on the left was captioned, ‘A view
of the drawing rooms which, with its cream

520.94.text:
walls and simple attractive furniture, forms
an effective backdrop for the pieces of sculpture

526.62.text:
in the room’. The image on the right was
captioned, ‘A view of the house from the

532.48.text:
studio showing the delightful paved garden
and fountain’. This one, ‘Corner of the

539.79.text:
dining room showing how the groups of sculpture
harmonise with the old oak furniture in the

544.52.text:
room’. And on the left here, ‘Lady Hilton
Young’s studio, in the far corner is a plaster

553.20.text:
cast of a head of Lord Northcliffe’ and
the one on the right, ‘The sculptress at

557.91.text:
work outside her studio on a figure of Edwin
Montagu’. And this final one from the article,

569.16.text:
‘The garden looking towards the studio’.
With all these illustrations in this particular

574.30.text:
article I think it's interesting, the captions,
they're always, kind of, linking the domestic

579.20.text:
with her work.
In this particular image, the work we’re

583.49.text:
looking at here, the statue, is called These
had most to give. I've just popped this in,

589.16.text:
not strictly a portrait but to, kind of, give
a slightly rounder picture of her work. This

595.39.text:
was one of Scott’s idealised figures of
young male nudes from 1923 so this, kind of,

600.56.text:
belongs to her other category of work. The
work was intended to be a war memorial and

605.46.text:
is arguably her most important ideal sculpture.
The model is 18 year old Arnold Lawrence,

612.23.text:
brother of T. E. Lawrence. Despite being widely
displayed and attracting awards no sale resulted

619.23.text:
and the sculpture stayed in her garden until
1933 when she presented it to the Scott Polar

624.11.text:
Research Institute in Cambridge, where she
also sculpted a head of Scott to go on a niche

629.58.text:
above the entrance. It would eventually stand
as a memorial to the polar expedition despite

635.16.text:
the incongruity of its nudity. The statue
was nearly bought for the Tate Gallery by

640.51.text:
Sir Joseph Duveen who was very keen on Scott’s
work. However, in the end he gave the gallery

646.20.text:
her 1913 bust of Herbert Asquith.
In the Queen magazine article Scott’s considerable

653.41.text:
achievements were referred to, placing her
at the forefront of English sculptors. The

659.69.text:
reviewer painted a vivid picture for the magazine’s
readers. The house was described as, and I

665.49.text:
quote, “deliciously early Victorian with
its delicately wrought iron balconies and

669.93.text:
shelter over the front door”. Her studio
was characterised by the writer as, and again

675.70.text:
I quote, “one of the most beautiful and
workmanlike I've ever seen, built of white

680.31.text:
cement and has great windows and doors painted
a bright blue. It is so planned that on the

685.76.text:
darkest of London days the studio is filled
with light” and it was described as containing,

691.80.text:
“a veritable gallery of celebrities.”
Other photographs in this extensively-illustrated

698.19.text:
review firmly placed Scott within a combined
domestic and working environment. Put together

704.77.text:
the text and photographs provided the contemporary
reader with a vivid sense of the artist’s

709.66.text:
living and working situation. This emphasis
on the domestic was mirrored in the ongoing

716.02.text:
interest in sculpture for the home, beginning
with a statuette and developed in mid-century

721.37.text:
through the Arts Council’s ‘Sculpture
in the Home’ series of Exhibitions.

726.76.text:
We might make a link between the photograph
seen here of Kathleen Scott’s home and studio

731.76.text:
as part of this broad interest in art within
a domestic environment. To move towards a

737.56.text:
more intimate sculpture appeared alongside
a stress on modelling and detail, largely

743.48.text:
through the medium of bronze, such smaller
works were in opposition to the grandeur of

748.23.text:
preceding statues. The viewer was required
to move closer. These works were redefined

755.05.text:
as domestic in concept and thus took on a
new role, literally within the home and figuratively

761.02.text:
in public exhibitions. For such context Scott
made both stand-alone statuettes as well as

767.42.text:
reduced versions of her life size portrait,
bust and statues.

773.46.text:
Clearly the home has always displayed objects
of a personal nature but the presentation

778.50.text:
of sculpture in the home became more specific
in the early twentieth century. Art journals

784.24.text:
such as The Studio as well as books and articles
on interior design informed viewers how they

789.69.text:
should show sculptures. An example of a Scott
statuette is this porcelain sculpture of Colonel

796.76.text:
T. E. Lawrence from 1921. It was noted how
unusual it was that the notoriously shy Colonel

804.40.text:
Lawrence had allowed Scott to make both this
porcelain statuette as well as a bronze version.

810.04.text:
In 1923 she showed at the Grosvenor Gallery.
A reviewer believed that the main characteristic

816.76.text:
of her work was, and I quote, “Its intense
virility, it might well be the work of a male

823.11.text:
sculptor and one could imagine that a spectator
ignorant of the artist’s sex might take

828.66.text:
K. Hilton Young to be a man.”
In 1936 she had a show at Ackerman’s Gallery

835.81.text:
in Bond Street and thanks to Lord Kennet’s
thoroughness we have some photographs of the

842.06.text:
installation. One review noted that this exhibition
had attracted much attention in artistic circles.

851.07.text:
It was felt that her portraits were “unusually
forceful” for a female sculptor and that

856.73.text:
this aspect was her strength. One example
is her 1922 sculpted bust of The Rt. Hon.

864.49.text:
David Lloyd George. This work with its emphasis
on the brow and hair received wide press coverage

871.34.text:
as did her over life-size bust of King George
V from 1935.

876.32.text:
According to Scott’s biography the king
offered her a £100 to destroy an Epstein

884.24.text:
bust that he’d particularly disliked, so
they were obviously on the same page with

888.38.text:
Epstein. This unusually large portrait showing
the king in naval uniform is shown at the

894.88.text:
Royal Academy in 1935. A review in Country
Life described it as a good likeness as well

901.19.text:
as a, and I quote, “dignified and vital
monument which should have been given the

906.33.text:
place of honour at the RA occupied by Sir
William Reid Dick’s rather lifeless marble

911.48.text:
bust in the central hall.”
Another article again compared the two sculptures

917.14.text:
describing the Reid Dick work as “conventional”,
whereas Scott’s employed, and I quote again,

922.05.text:
“a rougher and more powerful technique which
manages to convey a much finer picture of

928.20.text:
the sovereign and becomes a better work.”
These comments may be related to this work

934.80.text:
on the right which Is the plaster bust that
was prepared for Reid Dick’s nine foot stone

939.69.text:
statue to the King unveiled after the war.
This is not entirely clear as records made

945.96.text:
clear the existence of two separate works
on the same subject, an earlier marble portrait

950.99.text:
bust and the later over life-sized statue.
But if this is indeed the Reid Dick work referred

958.00.text:
to then the plaudits for the Scott version
seem valid.

962.76.text:
Scott’s 1936 bust of Neville Chamberlain
also attracted must attention including much

971.01.text:
coverage in the press as can be seen in the
right hand image from the Birmingham Post,

976.23.text:
showing Scott at work on the Chancellor’s
portrait. The sculpture was warmly praised

981.05.text:
as maintaining dignity yet going beyond the
popular image of the ‘Iron Chancellor’.

988.01.text:
Also well-received was Scott’s portraits
of George Bernard Shaw, especially the final

992.57.text:
one from 1938. This impressive work is a life-sized
half-length portrayal of Shaw, her third portrait

1000.57.text:
of him when the writer was 82 and in poor
health. As I've touched on Scott also produced

1008.67.text:
several large scale public works which have
a dual function as both portraits and memorials.

1014.98.text:
And as Ian’s stolen my thunder slightly
here, her most famous is probably that to

1020.20.text:
her first husband Robert Falcon Scott unveiled
in 1915 and located in Waterloo Place. Scott’s

1028.01.text:
monumental free standing statue is highly
visible because of its size, material and

1033.31.text:
genre and its placement on a tall granite
pedestal in a central London square. In this

1042.08.text:
work Scott is shown in full polar exploration
attire, his right hand outstretched and holding

1047.25.text:
a skiing stick. This over life-size statue
was unveiled by Mr Balfour who apparently

1053.54.text:
said, “...now at last we’ve got a good
statue in London.”

1058.67.text:
Scott died in 1947 and in the following year
a memorial exhibition was organised at Heal

1064.36.text:
& Son’s Mansard Gallery, a venue which played
a significant role in promoting sculpture

1069.08.text:
for the home. Unsurprisingly the catalogue
emphasised the prominence of Scott’s sitters

1074.96.text:
and thus the fame of her sculptures through
association. Some of Scott’s statues were

1081.46.text:
also produced as statuette editions. Works
in plaster could be cast in bronze by arrangement

1087.97.text:
so many very prominent works were apparently
available in editions as at the 1936 Ackerman

1094.34.text:
Gallery exhibition, included in the sculptures
of George V and this of Australian poet Adam

1101.28.text:
Lindsay Gordon.
Made in 1933 this sculpture was paid for by

1108.26.text:
public subscription to be placed in Poets'
Corner in Westminster Abbey. The deeply lined

1114.22.text:
face was described as providing a marked contrast
to the milder features of the other sculpted

1119.49.text:
occupants of Poets’ Corner. It was believed
that Scott’s success in portrait sculpture

1125.43.text:
was due to her close relationship with her
sitters, all of whom were highly successful

1129.92.text:
in their field. T. M. Trevelyan opened the
memorial exhibition and made reference to

1135.80.text:
the domestic and decorative possibilities
of sculpture and he said, “I'm glad this

1141.30.text:
exhibition and sale is being held on Heal’s
premises because one of the merits of her

1146.67.text:
portrait busts and ideal figures is that they
fit into people’s rooms and gardens.”

1151.23.text:
Sculpture is apt to be formidable and the
place that it can be induced to take in the

1156.39.text:
home is a difficult problem, which interested
her and which she did something to solve.

1163.86.text:
We can draw several further conclusions as
to why Scott is being marginalised within

1168.05.text:
art history. She belonged to the generation
of sculptors who came between the new sculpture

1173.52.text:
practitioners and Modernists such as Moore
and Hepworth. She was also vehemently anti-feminist

1180.43.text:
and this has exempted her from this particular
revisionist framework. Women sculptors in

1188.14.text:
general have been under-researched. There
were more female painters than sculptors in

1192.31.text:
the early twentieth century and historians
have tended to focus on the larger group.

1197.17.text:
Then there is the long-held assumption that
women were physically incapable of producing

1202.37.text:
sculpture which must have affected contemporary
attitudes, as did the common opinion that

1208.89.text:
sculpture made by women was invariably inferior
or largely produced by male assistants. In

1216.42.text:
addition, many female sculptors and painters
have mostly left scant written material, apart

1223.55.text:
from letters and diaries, which can be arbitrary
in scope and over-personalised in content.

1231.39.text:
Add to that a lack of formal archives, and
Scott is one of the very few exceptions in

1236.48.text:
having a decent archive, and the fact that
early exhibition catalogues comprised either

1242.65.text:
a list of works or pages of photographs without
accompanying text, and the problems pile up.

1249.82.text:
Tantalisingly, such catalogues do confirm
the existence a very large number of women

1255.26.text:
sculptors but pursuing these references any
further presents huge challenges. Where works

1263.59.text:
do survive they are largely held privately
or in regional collections and often not on

1268.91.text:
display.
More broadly, one of the issues that has bedevilled

1273.46.text:
accounts of early twentieth century British
sculpture is the emphasis on carving as an

1278.52.text:
expression of modernity thus downgrading modelling.
The focus on effort and the projection of

1285.83.text:
an individual personality implicated an avant-garde
practice was not helpful for female sculptors

1292.42.text:
who had to contend with the social and cultural
expectations of them as women. Direct carving

1299.55.text:
was also understood as representing honest
labour, heterosexual manliness, and resistance

1306.97.text:
to effeminacy.
The difficulties for women sculptors in this

1311.33.text:
context are clear, both in terms of what they
might practically achieve and the critical

1316.94.text:
responses to their sculptures. Since the doctrine
of carving impacted on male sculptures as

1323.61.text:
well, the depth of this problem becomes even
more apparent. Thank you.
